column1: #TonyMcLoughlin	unknown-#TonyMcLoughlin-party	unknown-#TonyMcLoughlin-dob	unknown-#TonyMcLoughlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	176	The programme for Government commits to improving overall access to mental health services in this country. On this basis
column2: will the Taoiseach please advise the House as to the progress of the delivery of recommendations of A Vision for Change? I ask this because
column3: as I am sure he is aware after his meeting with Sharon Boles last week during his visit to Sligo
column4: we urgently need a Jigsaw-like youth mental health service established in Sligo and Leitrim.We need improved resources for our Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services
column5: CAMHS
column6: in the region to reduce long waiting lists and the appointment of a lead consultant psychiatrist for this service as a matter of urgency.

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	177	I have sent a note to the Minister of State with responsibility for mental health services
column2: Deputy McEntee
column3: arising from the meeting I had in Sligo with Deputy McLoughlin and Ms Sharon Boles in respect of several queries about facilities for mental health in the Sligo area. The process of appointment of a consultant is a separate matter the Health Service Executive
column4: HSE
column5: will work on. I expect the Minister of State will respond to Deputy McLoughlin in time.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	178	Is the Minister of State replying now?

#HelenMcEntee	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-party	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-dob	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	179	Yes. In respect of A Vision for Change
column2: we have implemented almost 80% of the recommended positions
column3: that is
column4: more than 8.500 staff. Several other positions have been approved but we are having difficulty filling the vacancies. With regard to Jigsaw
column5: five more will open this year and there will be a new process for other counties to put themselves forward to open Jigsaw services too.

column1: #WillieODea	unknown-#WillieODea-party	unknown-#WillieODea-dob	unknown-#WillieODea-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	180	The Companies (Accounting) Bill 2016 was published last August. It provides for a simplified system of accounting for small and medium-sized enterprises
column2: SMEs
column3: that will save money and time and minimise bureaucracy. This legislation arises from a European directive that was adopted three years ago and our competitors already have put in place similar legislation with the result that Irish SMEs have been operating at a competitive disadvantage for the past two years. There is a general inquiry to know when exactly the legislation will be put in place.

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	181	It will be on Report Stage in this House the week after next.

#SeanHaughey	unknown-#SeanHaughey-party	unknown-#SeanHaughey-dob	unknown-#SeanHaughey-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	182	There is a commitment in the programme for Government for a new emergency department in Beaumont Hospital in North Dublin. The hospital opened in 1987
column2: 30 years ago
column3: and there has been no major investment during that time. It is operating at maximum capacity. That area has a large elderly population and a large growing population. Has the HSE capital programme for 2017 been drafted? Have Ministers seen it? Is this project part of that capital programme and when will this long-promised project go ahead?

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	183	The HSE has approval for 2017
column2: which the Minister has accepted. I cannot advise in detail on the proposition for a new emergency department at Beaumont Hospital but I will ask the Minister to respond directly to Deputy Haughey.

column1: #LouiseOReilly	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-party	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-dob	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	184	I wish the Taoiseach a happy International Women's Day and remind him that alcohol is one of the leading contributors to breast cancer
column2: a disease which sadly kills many women in this country. Yesterday the Minister of State at the Department of Health
column3: Deputy Corcoran Kennedy
column4: launched a new website
column5: www.askaboutalcohol.ie and encouraged us all to think about and manage our drinking. Sinn Féin strongly welcomes this website. I was a little disturbed to hear that the Minister of State is reflecting on the discussions to date in the Oireachtas because I think those are the discussions which take place at the Fine Gael parliamentary party meeting
column6: since there has been very little discussion on the floor of the House of the Public Health (Alcohol) Bill 2016. This Bill is now a year old and we need it expedited as a matter of urgency. On International Women's Day
column7: given that alcohol contributes to breast cancer
column8: when will this legislation progress?

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	185	Reflection is a very important part of the democratic process. When people raise issues of concern and in the public interest those should be reflected upon. This Bill is on Committee Stage in the Seanad and has to take its course there where Members will want to contribute and do their business before it comes here. We are not guillotining Bills any more. Let people have their say as they wish. The Minister of State
column2: Deputy Corcoran Kennedy is perfectly correct to reflect carefully on issues raised by Deputies from any part of the House or indeed by Members of the Seanad.

column1: #JamesLawless	unknown-#JamesLawless-party	unknown-#JamesLawless-dob	unknown-#JamesLawless-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	186	Last November I raised the question of community employment
column2: CE
column3: schemes
column4: and the difficulty many community organisations were having in finding and retaining individuals in these schemes. This arises from a decision to change the rules last summer
column5: implemented by the Minister for Social Protection.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	187	Is the Deputy talking about legislation or the programme for Government?

#JamesLawless	unknown-#JamesLawless-party	unknown-#JamesLawless-dob	unknown-#JamesLawless-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	188	It is in the programme for Government
column2: page 52
column3: section P. In response to me at the time and to colleagues who have raised the issue since then
column4: the Minister referred to a report that was pending on how CE schemes are and would be implemented. I am concerned that there is an ideological issue at play here. Some
column5: including the Minister
column6: see the CE schemes as a means to an end with job activation as the ultimate goal. Others see them as an end in themselves where individuals can contribute constructively within a structured format in their communities which is mutually beneficial to the individual and the host organisation. When will the report the Minister mentioned issue? Is it imminent? What side does the Taoiseach see it coming down on?

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	189	The Government recently heard a report from the Minister on this where he said he is anxious to change the construction of CE schemes to allow more people participate in them. I expect he will bring this to public attention very shortly. The intention is to continue CE schemes but because of the rising rate of employment there is a different category available for CE schemes and the Minister is anxious to facilitate that.

column1: #MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	204	I move: That leave be granted to introduce a Bill entitled an Act to amend the Statute of Limitations 1957 to bring the issue of Circuit Court and High Court Judgments into line with the most recent bankruptcy legislation
column2: by reducing the lifetime of High Court and Circuit Court Judgments from 12 years to two years
column3: and reduce the Statute of Limitations from six years to two years in instances where the collection and enforcement of civil debt by Banks and Vulture funds are concerned.The law of limitations in Ireland is governed by the Statute of Limitations 1957
column4: which sets out the statutory rules regarding the various time limits available to a person or body seeking to initiate a civil claim against another person. The 1957 statute defines seven categories of limitation periods. For example
column5: the time limit for taking a personal injury claim is two years
column6: whereas the time limit for taking a claim based on a contract debt
column7: such as a debt owed to a financial institution
column8: is six years. A subsequent judgment taken by such an institution can be extended to a further 12 years. This Bill seeks to amend two categories of limitation period within the Statute of Limitations legislation. Its aim is to reduce the current time limit from six years to two years in the case of a civil claim based on a contract debt such as a loan from a bank. The Bill also seeks to reduce the lifetime of High Court and Circuit Court judgments from 12 years to two
column9: which would be in line with the most recent bankruptcy legislation. In fact
column10: judgments currently run well in excess of the Statute of Limitations - by six years or so - and are
column11: therefore
column12: well out of line with the statute as it applies to contract debt. Strangely enough
column13: the debts and judgments of a deceased person become barred under the statute after two years
column14: which is the current objective of this amendment for both living people and corporates. It seems that under current legislation
column15: living people must face a worse fate than death and are expected to continue to exist in limbo for six to 12 years. The Bill we are introducing is based on the experiences our offices have had over the past six years in dealing with people throughout Ireland who are in debt or have a debt hanging over them. The legislation is also guided by a report produced by the Law Reform Commission in 2011
column16: which recommended that the length of a civil claim based on a contract debt should be reduced from six years to two. The commission queried why certain civil claims
column17: such as personal injury claims
column18: have a two-year limit while the contract debt limit remains at six years. The current time limit of six years could be in breach of Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights
column19: which is incorporated into Irish law under the European Convention on Human Rights Act 2003. Article 6 of the convention states
column20: "everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing within a reasonable time by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law". It seems to be a blatant breach of the Article 6 entitlement to a "hearing within a reasonable time" that it is possible for a civil claim to hang over someone for six years and then be initiated at the last minute. Our State-owned and partially State-owned banks are currently wielding the 12-year judgment axe over considerable numbers of customers who
column21: for one reason or another
column22: do not wish to go through the insolvency or bankruptcy route but who are making their best efforts to settle with those banks. The manner in which the last ounce of blood is being extracted from these people means they are suffering to a much greater extent. The existing outdated legislation is putting them at a disadvantage
column23: to say the least. The recent influx into Ireland of vulture funds such as Cerberus
column24: which has bought a substantial amount of debt from our banks and from NAMA
column25: is adding to this problem. To put it in perspective
column26: Cerberus has bought €13.5 billion of par debt loans from NAMA over the past three years. It has bought well over €20 billion of such loans in total when its purchases from Ulster Bank are included. I reiterate that these vultures are wielding the 12-year judgment axe to frighten already distressed borrowers who have been sold out by the State in recent times. A large slice of Ireland has been sold to these vultures at a fraction of its real value. The Minister
column27: Deputy Noonan
column28: has said that the term "vulture fund" is "a compliment" because "vultures provide a very good service in the ecology through cleaning up dead animals that are littered across the landscape". It is not surprising that the Minister has become their cheerleader
column29: particularly in view of the number of times he has had meetings with vulture funds. He would do well to remember that the dead animals the vultures are cleaning up are the Irish people
column30: some of whom are well into their 70s and 80s. I am sure every Deputy will agree that we would not like to see our fellow countrymen treated in this way. Two of the purposes of this legislation are to discourage plaintiffs - those taking cases - from delaying the initiation of proceedings and to protect defendants from having the cloud of litigation hanging over their heads for six years
column31: or up to 12 years in the case of judgments. More particularly
column32: this Bill seeks to bring the timing of these outmoded statutes into line with recent bankruptcy and insolvency legislation
column33: thereby providing a fair playing pitch for all.

#EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	209	I propose to take Questions Nos. 1 to 5
column2: inclusive
column3: together. Since the UK referendum last June
column4: I have had an intensive series of bilateral meetings with my counterparts in EU member states and with the heads of the EU institutions. I have attended all formal and informal meetings of the European Council. At all my meetings
column5: I have highlighted and explained Ireland’s particular concerns arising from Brexit
column6: including those relating to Northern Ireland and the peace process
column7: the common travel area
column8: our interwoven economies and the future of the EU. I met first Vice President of the Commission
column9: Frans Timmermans
column10: in Government Buildings on 21 February last. His visit followed those of other Commissioners
column11: including Mr. Moscovici and Ms Vestager
column12: which have served to underline the Commission's understanding of Ireland's particular concerns and support for our approach.  The meeting was constructive
column13: with Commissioner Timmermans demonstrating a good understanding of Ireland's concerns and offering strong Commission support for our approach in addressing them. I visited Brussels on 23 February to meet the Prime Minister of Belgium
column14: Charles Michel
column15: and the President of the European Commission
column16: Jean-Claude Juncker. I also participated in a business event organised by the Ireland Belgium Business Association and supported by the Irish Embassy and Enterprise Ireland. As I continued this strategic programme of engagement
column17: I travelled to Brussels again on 2 March for separate meetings with the President of the European Council
column18: Donald Tusk
column19: the recently elected President of the European Parliament
column20: Antonio Tajani
column21: a number of key Members of the European Parliament and the chief Commission Brexit negotiator
column22: Michel Barnier. The focus of these meetings was on Brexit as well as the future direction of the EU. In addition to setting out our concerns around the economic and trade implications of the UK departure
column23: I again explained in detail the peace process in Northern Ireland
column24: the Good Friday Agreement and the unique circumstances on the island of Ireland that must be recognised from the start and reflected in the final agreement.  President Tusk
column25: President Tajani and Mr. Barnier understood and acknowledged these issues and expressed their openness to working closely with us in the forthcoming negotiations. It was useful to highlight these issues to key MEPs. As the European Parliament will adopt a resolution on Brexit in the coming months and will ultimately have to approve the final exit deal
column26: it is important that we continue to engage to seek support there. With regard to the debate on the future of the EU
column27: I underlined to all my interlocutors the need for unity and the importance of our core European values
column28: which are central to our continuing peace and prosperity. We must deliver for our citizens and
column29: in that context
column30: press ahead in areas of particular relevance
column31: including jobs
column32: growth
column33: investment
column34: the Single Market and the digital single market. I will continue to make these points in the build-up to the summit in Rome at the end of this month and into the future. The next European Council meeting will take place on 9 March next. The draft agenda that has been published by the general secretariat of the Council envisages that the Maltese Presidency will provide an overview of progress on the implementation of earlier European Council conclusions and that the European Council will look at a number of the most pressing issues
column35: including those relating to jobs
column36: growth and competitiveness; security and defence; migration; and external relations. Decisions are also to be taken on the position of the President of the European Council and the establishment of a European public prosecutor's office. The agenda is in order from Ireland's perspective. Therefore
column37: I have not sought any particular items for inclusion on it. I will be making a full statement in advance of the European Council meeting

#MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	211	The Taoiseach has indicated to my party leader

column9: who represent a majority of citizens

#EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	219	The Cabinet sub-committee on Brexit met this morning at 8 o'clock and we went through all the preparatory work that has been ongoing for quite some time. When the British Prime Minister triggers Article 50
column2: it means she will write a formal letter to President Tusk of the European Council indicating formal notice of Britain's intention to leave the European Union. The Government will respond to that directly because at least we will have some further clarity - particularly with regard to trade and the customs union - on what the British Government is seeking. We have agreed that what it will look for is as close a relationship as is possible with the European Union. That would suit Ireland. Clearly
column3: if a country is removed from the Single Market
column4: with a changed status in respect of the customs unions
column5: these issues become politically very challenging. The Government will respond in considerable detail directly after Article 50 is triggered on how we intend to negotiate our position. I have set out the priorities on this already.

column1: #EamonRyanGP	unknown-#EamonRyanGP-party	unknown-#EamonRyanGP-dob	unknown-#EamonRyanGP-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	220	I wish to ask about the future of Europe and the Taoiseach's discussions in that regard
column2: particularly at the meeting on 2 March. The European Commission has set out five options for the future of Europe. These include: carrying on; having nothing but the Single Market; those who to do so doing more; doing less more efficiently; or doing much more together. Has the Taoiseach had any sense in his discussions as to which of those five scenarios the Irish Government would see as our future? I am conscious of his statement to the effect that he will press ahead in respect of areas of common interest and that these are all economic. I have a slight concern that we are not looking at social
column3: environmental or other issues
column4: and that what the Taoiseach referred to all relates to one area. Did the Taoiseach give an indication of what would be the approach of the Government in responding to the Commission's scenarios to set out our vision of our role in the future of Europe? I was shocked to see some VoteWatch analysis recently which identifies Ireland as probably the most negative country on just about any suggestion for the development of Europe. It is opposed to economic integration
column5: tax harmonisation and defence co-operation. There was also a categorisation of the responses from governments to date. Eastern countries are very nervous about a segregated or two-speed approach but western governments are possibly in favour of that. Northern and Scandinavian governments are looking for neither of those. Where did the Taoiseach place us when he spoke with either members of the Commission or President Tusk on the future of Europe White Paper?

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	221	With regard to Deputy McDonald's latter point
column2: we have special status as we stand in that we are the only country with a peace process supported by the European Union and an international legally-binding agreement. We want to build on that and we will have a much clearer view once Article 50 is triggered. I made the point that there can be all-island agreements in respect of a number of areas if there is a willingness shown in that regard. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade
column3: Deputy Flanagan
column4: is in Belfast today working with the parties and the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland and we hope an Executive and an Assembly can be put together. In respect of the issues that Deputy Eamon Ryan raised
column5: from a European perspective
column6: the critical issues
column7: particularly for the western Balkans
column8: the countries of which are experiencing pressure from Russia
column9: are migration
column10: security and defence and NATO matters. We must also consider comments made by the new American Administration about participation in NATO in future if spending does not rise to 2% of gross domestic product. There are implications for Germany in this regard - a strong economic power - which might mean it being obliged to allocate €50 billion or €60 billion per year. The German people have been very reticent about this for good historic reasons but that is a matter for discussion. The Deputy mentioned a two-speed Europe. Ireland will be placed at the front and we do not want to be left behind in any way. We want to be part of a social Europe. We will not be left behind because we have put our point as being central to Europe and the eurozone. That is where we intend to stay.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	222	It is fair to say that there has been welcome reassurance from the European institutions that they understand the Border issue on this island and that it is unique in the context of the Brexit negotiations. There is no evident move to go beyond very broad generalities. British Prime Minister May has stated she wants a red
column2: white and blue Brexit
column3: which is not very reassuring to all those who do not share her British nationalist policies. Mr. Tony Connolly spoke about the Border issue on RTE last night and he is among the correspondents who have made the consistent point that there has been comment in Brussels about how Ireland has been successful in raising concerns but that so far we have not offered concrete solutions. For some reason
column4: we have not finished an economic impact assessment. At this stage
column5: I am concerned we are not offering the level of detail needed to guide negotiations to a good outcome. The civil dialogue confirms that businesses on both sides of the Border are terrified of the impact of the new customs and trade regulations that are now inevitable. With regard to supply chains
column6: queuing at Border crossings is not the issue but rather the paperwork and multiple duties. Mr. Connolly captured that well last night in discussing similar border issues in different parts of the EU. The only way we can realistically tackle that is with some form of special economic zone or customs zone to be established for Northern Ireland
column7: or at the very least for Border counties. Is the Taoiseach proposing anything specific for the negotiations on these issues? Are there any required technical papers being prepared at this stage?

column1: #SeanHaughey	unknown-#SeanHaughey-party	unknown-#SeanHaughey-dob	unknown-#SeanHaughey-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	223	I have a related question on Article 50 being invoked and the Taoiseach's discussion and contact with Mr. Michel Barnier and Mr. Guy Verhofstadt who represent the European Commission and the European Parliament
column2: respectively. Does the Taoiseach have any sense they are prepared to deal with Ireland's special circumstances up-front and that once Article 50 and the framework for discussions are agreed
column3: with people making their opening statements in the European Parliament or wherever
column4: Ireland's special position will be recognised in that framework of discussions? That is both from the perspective of the Commission and Parliament. There is increasing talk of a multi-speed Europe
column5: with more sentiments expressed during the week about that from those who want to press ahead with further integration in a two-speed Europe. What is the Irish Government's view on that?It is not in the spirit of why Ireland joined the EEC and
column6: subsequently
column7: the EU. I would welcome a clear statement from the Taoiseach about these ongoing suggestions of a two-speed Europe.

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	224	As I have said on many occasions
column2: we are still not clear about a number of issues regarding the British Government's position. When the Prime Minister writes the letter on behalf of the British Government and triggers Article 50
column3: we will respond to it in detail. A great deal of preparatory work has been done
column4: as the Deputy is well aware. All the options in the different sectors have been set out and considered. We need to know what we are dealing with so we can respond to it. The negotiations are led by the Barnier task force and the Commission and we feed our concerns into it. The Government will respond in detail when Article 50 has been triggered. No work is under way regarding the acquisition of land for Border customs posts. There was some talk about it some time ago. Our political position is that there will be no return to the Border of the past
column5: and this is agreed and accepted by the British Government. It is a political challenge. It is not a technological or a paper issue. It is a political priority. I was in Kiltyclogher in County Leitrim recently. During the Troubles
column6: Leitrim was the only county from which one could not get to Northern Ireland. Every road was blown up. The people there who are in their senior years never want to go back to that situation
column7: and neither do we. The Deputy mentioned a special economic zone. These are matters for consideration. My starting point is that there would be no return to that Border. There is political agreement on it that whatever will happen will be consequent on the nature of the relationship the UK wants with Europe from then on
column8: clearly with implications for Ireland. One of the four priorities set out by Michel Barnier
column9: as head of the Brexit task force
column10: is to deal with the question of Northern Ireland and the Border. He is well aware of the difference between this and Catalonia
column11: which is a Spanish issue
column12: or Gibraltar
column13: which is a Spanish-British issue. Ours is the subject of an international
column14: legally binding agreement. Deputy Haughey asked a good question about the multi-speed Europe issue
column15: which has been around for a while. Various ideas and proposals
column16: so-called "variable geometry"
column17: have always arisen in discussion about future developments of the EU. They are again being mentioned in the context of the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome. We have already had such a variable geometry regarding the euro and the Schengen Agreement. Enhanced co-operation has been included in the treaties for this reason and the provisions can be used to allow a group of states to move ahead if they wish with co-operation without all members supporting it. We want to stay in the vanguard
column18: right up at the front. If it transpires that there are two speeds operating in Europe
column19: we want to be at the higher speed and central to it.

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	225	I propose to take Questions Nos. 6 to 8
column2: inclusive
column3: together. I spoke by telephone to Prime Minister Theresa May on Sunday following the outcome of the Northern Ireland Assembly elections. We agreed to speak again when we meet tomorrow
column4: Thursday
column5: at the European Council in Brussels. During our phone conversation we agreed that early engagement by the political parties in Northern Ireland is required with a view to re-establishing a functioning Executive as soon as possible
column6: and to address outstanding issues under the agreements. We also agreed that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade
column7: Deputy Charles Flanagan
column8: and the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland
column9: James Brokenshire
column10: would engage together with the parties over the coming days. They are to meet in Belfast today
column11: and are probably meeting as we speak. There is a three week window for the formation of a new Executive. The political parties have each received fresh mandates. Particular responsibilities attach to the two parties
column12: the Democratic Unionist Party
column13: DUP
column14: and Sinn Féin
column15: which are entitled to nominate a First Minister and deputy First Minister to engage with each other and to advance discussions with all eligible political parties on the formation of a new Executive. Dealing with outstanding issues from previous agreements will be necessary to create confidence at this critical moment for devolution in Northern Ireland. All parties eligible to nominate Ministers to the Executive will be invited to participate in these discussions which
column16: in accordance with previous agreements
column17: will be facilitated by the two Governments. That is why the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Secretary of State are there today. The Minister
column18: Deputy Charles Flanagan
column19: has spoken to party leaders to congratulate them on the electoral mandate they have achieved and to encourage them to play their part in creating the conditions that allow for the formation of a new power-sharing Assembly and Executive. The heart of the Good Friday Agreement is its interlocking political institutions. However
column20: they can only be sustained on the basis of partnership
column21: equality and mutual respect. As a co-guarantor
column22: the Irish Government is determined to uphold the principles of the Agreement and to protect its institutions. In the coming weeks
column23: we will work with all concerned to see the power-sharing Assembly and Executive restored to effective and harmonious operation. I hope it can happen.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	226	The Taoiseach will agree that the fundamental duty of everybody elected to the Northern Ireland Assembly last week is to work with others to get the institutions functioning in the interests of the people. Reports last night stated that the first day of discussions resulted in a Sinn Féin walk-out on funding for legacy issues. This is a far from encouraging start
column2: particularly given that it does not relate to the specific issue which brought down the Executive and on which the election was triggered. There is no evidence
column3: so far
column4: of any significant changes in the positions of any of the parties
column5: and the opening dynamic is not good
column6: to say the least. The drift and growing tribalism in the Executive during recent years happened at exactly the time when London and Dublin took a decision to step back and leave it to the DUP and Sinn Féin. If there is one clear lesson from recent years it is that disengagement by the two Governments is damaging and must be permanently reversed. The Minister for Foreign Affairs
column7: Deputy Charles Flanagan
column8: is participating in the talks. Will the Taoiseach assure us that he will continue to participate up to the point where a conclusion is reached? If the Northern Ireland Executive is not re-established soon
column9: what arrangements will be made to ensure Northern Ireland has a voice on Brexit? At the recent civic dialogue on Brexit
column10: the very clear message from those who spoke for Northern Ireland
column11: representing the civil dialogue
column12: was the absence of a coherent voice from Northern Ireland on Brexit and real alarm about the fact that people were not engaged in the most important issue to face Northern Ireland and the entire island in a generation.

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	227	I agree with the Deputy that it is the duty of everybody elected the Northern Ireland Assembly to see that the Assembly operates
column2: an Executive is set up and that it sets out an agreed set of objectives to be implemented. In the previous Executive
column3: the then First Minister
column4: Arlene Foster
column5: and Deputy First Minister
column6: Martin McGuinness
column7: agreed on a set of objectives and forwarded a formal notice of it to the British Prime Minister and to me. The Deputy's point is important. A democratic decision has been taken. There are changed numbers in respect of the parties. They have a duty to get together and I hope they can do so. The Minister
column8: Deputy Charles Flanagan
column9: will continue to engage on behalf of the Government as co-guarantor of the Good Friday Agreement and successive agreements. We will see the negotiations through. I do not like to assume the Members of the Legislative Assembly would automatically seek an extension beyond the three weeks. I have agreed with the British Prime Minister that a return to direct rule would not be in anybody's interests. I hope it can be dealt with in the three weeks. If not
column10: legislation will be introduced to extend the time or introduce direct rule. If it is not dealt with in the time
column11: the voices that were heard at the all-island sectoral forum will have to be transmitted as part of the negotiations.I have reflected on that so I hope that it will be possible for the Executive to be set up and to have a First Minister and deputy First Minister.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	228	It is not simply that the numbers have changed in the composition of the Assembly
column2: although that is true as Deputy Micheál Martin has noted. Something much more fundamental and significant has happened
column3: not least the fact that the Unionist majority in the Assembly is now gone. This changes everything and there needs to be a moment of reflection
column4: as the Taoiseach urged earlier
column5: for people to absorb that fact. Another thing has happened
column6: which is the absolute demand on the ground
column7: not just an expectation
column8: that agreed matters should be implemented. Sinn Féin does not need a pep talk from anybody in that regard. We are up for doing business. We want the power-sharing institutions to work. They can only work
column9: however
column10: on the basis of delivery. The Taoiseach is the co-guarantor of the Good Friday Agreement
column11: the St. Andrews Agreement and the Fresh Start agreement - the list is very lengthy - but the fact is that Dublin and London are in default in respect of commitments entered into and this needs to be fixed. From Sinn Féin's point of view it is not a case of us being obstructionist; we want the institutions. The message from the ground
column12: however
column13: is clear. Matters agreed must be delivered. I believe this to be a reasonable expectation in a democratic society. On the issue of the legacy inquests
column14: we welcomed the remarks by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade
column15: Deputy Charles Flanagan
column16: at the Pat Finucane lecture in which he urged the British Government to resource the legacy inquests and he backed the proposal of the Lord Chief Justice. This is essential. It would be £10 million in monetary terms and it is a confidence measure that is needed. I would like to make one other point if I could have a chance to come in.

#EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	238	The Assembly numbers have changed but it is very clear that there was a Brexit element to the vote and people were very clear in that. Obviously the parties will now get together. I am glad to hear the deputy leader of Sinn Féin say the party does not want to be obstructionist
column2: that it wants an Executive set up and an Assembly functioning. We all share the view that what has been agreed here should be implemented. I engaged with the then Prime Minister
column3: David Cameron
column4: on the Fresh Start agreement around legacy issues of the past. In dealing with Ballymurphy
column5: the hooded men
column6: Pat Finucane
column7: the Birmingham Six
column8: Kingsmill and so on
column9: the Fresh Start agreement contains the opportunity and the potential to address these. It has got to be tested. The theory is that if someone has lost a loved one or a family member and wishes to have the information supplied to him or her about all of the issues and circumstances surrounding that
column10: then it should be made available. That is the agreement. It could be made available through the independent
column11: objective adjudication of international and other figures. That is an issue we need to get back to. It was not possible to do it in Fresh Start but that is contained within that agreement. I agree that what has been agreed should be able to be implemented. There have been difficulties with this is in the past but it must be dealt with.

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	239	The two commissions of investigation currently under way for which I am the specified Minister under the Commissions of Investigation Act 2004
column2: are the Fennelly commission
column3: which was established in April 2014 and is chaired by Mr. Justice Nial Fennelly
column4: and the Irish Bank Resolution Corporation
column5: IBRC
column6: commission
column7: which was established in June 2015 and is chaired by Mr. Justice Brian Cregan. The commissions are independent in the performance of their functions and it would not be appropriate for me to comment on any aspects of their work.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	240	I thank the Taoiseach for his reply. Has he any indication as to when the Fennelly commission will report? It has been going on for quite some time now
column2: if I am not mistaken. Is there an update from the judge on the progress or lack thereof? As for the IBRC commission
column3: will we have an interim report from that inquiry at some stage? Has the Taoiseach had a further update on Project Eagle since the all-party meeting some months ago? As the report by the Committee of Public Accounts on Project Eagle is imminent
column4: the terms of reference on Project Eagle should be finalised as soon as possible. I thought we had agreed broad outlines of terms of reference at those meetings. My final question for the Taoiseach is around current inquiries. He will recall we had some discussion on this the last time. How many inquiries has the Government under its compass
column5: overall
column6: at the moment? How many inquiries are ongoing as we speak? Perhaps the Taoiseach will forward the information to me because I know it is not contained in this parliamentary question.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	242	Yes
column2: and their costs. I would appreciate if the Taoiseach could send on a written note to me in that regard. During our last discussion on this issue
column3: the Taoiseach said he was looking into the idea of a permanent unit to have responsibility for inquiries. We need to do some reflection - away from the issue of today - as to a template around the whole area of inquiries and how they are conducted. It is not easy but I know there were proposals in the past. In other jurisdictions there are specific departments to focus on this area. Equally with regard to performance within organisations
column4: all of these matters arise because they give rise to issues that have not been dealt with internally by organisations or by various other organisations that are meant to cover this. For example
column5: it is extraordinary the degree to which the Garda Síochána Ombudsman Commission does not seem to have the capacity - and nor do people have any confidence in it - as one agency that is supposed to deal with all the issues that arise from An Garda Síochána. In the area of health
column6: for example with the Grace case
column7: we are dealing with the lack of any internal dynamic that should kick in when something wrong takes place. The same has happened with the Tusla file in respect of Maurice McCabe. I read that file and the casualness with which it was dealt with internally by the organisation is quite shocking and striking. All of this is leading to-----

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	244	I apologise.

#EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	245	The Fennelly commission is due to report this year by the end of March 2017. There may be some slight delay on that depending on the responses received by Mr. Justice Nial Fennelly. It is due by the end of March and the cost to date has been €3.106 million. On IBRC
column2: the timeframe on the final report for the first module of its work regarding the Siteserv transaction is the end of December 2017. With regard to Project Eagle
column3: I met the party leaders on all of that. We felt it better that
column4: as the report of the Committee of Public Accounts is pending publication
column5: we should wait to see what its observations or recommendations are in respect of Project Eagle. We need to consider the findings and conclusions of that report when it is published. It may contain information that would need to be factored in to terms of reference for the commission of investigation we have already agreed on. We would need to consider the likelihood of a commission of investigation being able to get any further relevant information for the commission about the issues involved
column6: bearing in mind the large amount of evidence it has already received from NAMA and from other interested parties. It is an important point to bear in mind given the substantial funding involved. There is €4.7 million in the Department's Vote for 2017 and this includes provision for the Fennelly commission due to report at the end of March
column7: as I have said
column8: and the first element of the Siteserv module of IBRC
column9: due by the end of this year. While there was an element of €10 million provided for the proposed commission of investigation into Project Eagle
column10: based on the estimated cost of the IBRC commission it is not possible at this stage to be sure what might actually fall due for payment in 2017. If the funding available is not sufficient
column11: we will have to find the resources from within the Department or somewhere else. I have referred before to the permanent structure. The Law Reform Commission made recommendations on this and considered it was not appropriate. However
column12: it did consider there were some other valuable elements and I am considering those.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	246	I want to raise two issues. First
column2: in respect of the commission on NAMA and Project Eagle
column3: I hear a kind of reticence in the Taoiseach's presentation that there is somehow a question mark over whether there will in fact be a commission. When we undertook our examination in the PAC
column4: it was never understood or intended to be an alternative to the commission we had all agreed to and signed up to in principle. I would like the Taoiseach to confirm for us that the commission will in fact go ahead. I understand the Taoiseach needs the report from the PAC to be factored into the terms of reference and I think that reasonable. However
column5: he should not be using the PAC as a means of not carrying forward the commission. I would like him to confirm that. Second
column6: on the mother and baby homes
column7: I earlier raised the issues around Tuam with the Taoiseach. I think he made a commitment
column8: although he might confirm this
column9: that he would meet and consult with victims
column10: survivors and advocacy groups. As he does that
column11: one of the core things that needs to be considered is the particular issue of legal representation for survivors because they are currently cast as onlookers or spectators in an inquiry that has had the most traumatic consequences for them and their lives.

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	247	I met on 4 October last year with the party leaders. We agreed in principle that the Government will establish a commission of investigation under the Act of 2004 to investigate any significant matters of public concern in regard to NAMA. The party leaders also agreed then that there will be limitations on the commission's work
column2: given the location of potential witnesses
column3: documentation outside the jurisdiction and ongoing criminal investigations. Since then
column4: the Committee of Public Accounts
column5: which is not an alternative to a commission of investigation
column6: has been holding hearings in regard to the Comptroller and Auditor General's report. It received a very large amount of evidence from NAMA and many interested parties
column7: including parties from outside this jurisdiction. We await the report of the PAC. After the PAC report is published
column8: we will see what it says
column9: and the Deputy will know more about that than I do
column10: given she is a member of the committee. We will need to consider any findings
column11: conclusions or recommendations that may be made by the committee. For example
column12: the PAC report may contain information that would need to be factored into the terms of reference that would be proposed for the commission. As I said
column13: we will also need to consider whether the commission of investigation would be able to find out other information beyond what has been considered by the PAC report. If information or personnel are outside the jurisdiction
column14: or if there are criminal investigations
column15: that puts limitations on what a commission of investigation might be able to do. That is not resiling from the decision in principle to have a commission of investigation into this matter. It is being realistic in the sense of what will be in the PAC report
column16: what are the matters it has considered
column17: what are the recommendations
column18: whether all work would be replicated by a commission of investigation and where are the areas that neither the PAC nor a commission of investigation has been able to go into because of the limitations of jurisdiction
column19: documentation or whatever. That is where the matter stands.

column1: #SeanHaughey	unknown-#SeanHaughey-party	unknown-#SeanHaughey-dob	unknown-#SeanHaughey-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	248	I think most Members would welcome a report in regard to the number of tribunals of inquiry and commissions of investigation that are underway at present
column2: or even if we could be told where to find that information. While I appreciate it is not under the ambit of the Department of the Taoiseach
column3: I want to refer to the possibility of a commission of investigation into the Stardust fire in 1981. I welcome the fact the former Deputy
column4: Mr. Justice Patrick McCartan
column5: has been appointed to do a scoping exercise. In the Taoiseach's capacity as head of Government
column6: can he give an assurance that Mr. Justice McCartan will be allowed to carry out his work independently
column7: given there are suggestions previous scoping exercises were interfered with by the relevant Department. Hopefully
column8: he can carry out his work independently. Then
column9: should he find that a commission of investigation is necessary
column10: I ask that this proceed without delay.

column1: #EndaKenny	unknown-#EndaKenny-party	unknown-#EndaKenny-dob	unknown-#EndaKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-03-08 00:00:00	Commission of Investigation (Certain Matters Relative to Disability Service in the South East and Related Matters): Motion (Resumed)	249	I will have a report circulated or made available to all Members on all the tribunals and commissions of investigation that are under way by Government across the entire spectrum. The Moriarty tribunal began 20 years ago and we are still paying for it. I can confirm for Deputy Haughey that the appointment of the former Deputy
column2: Mr. Justice Patrick McCartan
column3: was on the basis of his being a person of integrity and credibility who is trusted by the relatives of Stardust victims as being a fit person to carry out this scoping exercise. It is important to say that the issue which was flagged very strenuously at Government by the Minister of State
column4: Deputy Finian McGrath
column5: was that the scoping exercise of Mr. Justice McCartan is to investigate the new evidence that has come to light through the relatives of the victims of the Stardust fire. Mr. Justice McCartan will be allowed to do his work completely independently and there will be no interference from the Department in his work. I understand he will be able to do this pretty expeditiously. If he decides and recommends
column6: on the basis of that new evidence
column7: that a commission of investigation is warranted
column8: then that is the decision of Government. However
column9: it was only right and proper to reflect
column10: analyse and scrutinise the new evidence available and to see whether that warrants a new commission of investigation. If his recommendation is that it does
